findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop sales for all users excluding the owner, potentially operating as a honeypot.

findings.title: FRV - Fee Restoration Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract demonstrates a potential vulnerability upon removing and restoring the fees when the fees have been set to zero, leading to unintended consequences such as incorrect fee calculations or unexpected behavior within the contract.
findings.function: remove fees and restore fees functions

findings.title: ULF - Unused Liquidity Functionality
findings.description: The contract contains a private `addLiquidity` function designed to facilitate the addition of liquidity to a Uniswap V2 pool, but it is never invoked in any part of the contract's code.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that are initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. Declaring these variables as immutable can save gas by allowing the Solidity compiler to make certain optimizations.

findings.title: IFH - Inefficient Fee Handling
findings.description: The contract's `_tokenTransfer` function has redundant code and unnecessary complexity due to separate `if` conditions for fee management logic, leading to potential inefficiencies in gas usage and making the code harder to read and maintain.

findings.title: PLPI - Potential Liquidity Provision Inadequacy
findings.description: The contract operates under the assumption that liquidity is consistently provided to the pair between the contract's token and the native currency. However, there is a possibility that liquidity is provided to a different pair. This inadequacy in liquidity provision in the main pair could expose the contract to risks.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `treasuryWallet` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but the variable numTokensSellToAddToLiquidity sets a threshold that can trigger a huge token swap, potentially leading to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: RES - Redundant Event Statement
findings.description: The `MinTokensBeforeSwapUpdated` event statement is not used in the contract's implementation.

findings.title: RLF - Redundant Liquidity Functionality
findings.description: The contract contains redundant liquidity functionality due to permanently setting `_liquidityFee` to zero with no available method to modify or update this value post-deployment.

findings.title: RRS - Redundant Require Statement
findings.description: The contract utilizes a `require` statement within the `add` function aiming to prevent overflow errors, which is redundant due to Solidity version 0.8.0 and later reverting on overflow and underflow.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 provide native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert on underflow and overflow.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can occur due to conditional statements that are always false, functions that are never called, or unreachable code, making a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and increasing its size and deployment cost.
